gasgas and TheGariel,  
  
The fact is, this EA is a top-performing EA, especially with so much work put into it by Actionpl and Samurai Power and I give them all the credit for it. I personally believe the best way to run this EA is to drive it manually if you know how to determine the direction of the Trend fast and accurately, actually, that is what i'm testing with the latest version (manual driving) and it's yielding good result.  
  
The only 2 reasons i'm testing the fully-auto and posting the result are;  
1) I'm not really a smaller TF trader - so I checked the bigger TF with the EA - i believe that could reduce the excessive drawdowns - if i'm monitoring the H4 and Daily TFs to determine my trend why can't I trade on it.  
  
2) I believe that if the result continues to be good and consistent, somebody like Actionpl and other talented programmers on this thread will take it from there and perfect it for higher TF traders like me.  
  
I actually don't know if running the EA fully auto will be good long term, but I know its been giving very good result for the past 3 weeks and very low draw down. I tried back-testing the last 2 weeks on a simulator but the result wasn't as good as the actual result i got on live trading (forward testing), so, i'm not going to completely rely on the result of a strategy tester, the best way to find out is to forward test it for sometime and compare it with your backtest result for that period. Also, very important, I don't actually run the EA continously like that, I close all left-over trades before the London market opens on Sunday, i don't care if they are lost trades (as long as I'm in profit already), and I don't activate the EA until the London market opens on Monday morning (2AM EST). I guess that might answer your question - TheGabriel.  
  
PS: I'm trading both the semi-auto and fully-auto on my live accounts now. it's been good. I'm not recommending anyone to do this until you've tested it and satisfied with the result.  
  
Ayo.

Those message on left top corner are only there to give us some indcation of what is happening with the EA.  
Trade eanable: EA is ready to analyse the market since condition are met  
trade disable:: It meant that the EA will not trade due to filter parameters   
MarketAnalysis: The EA is checking the trend (if flag is on)  
Enterposition: The EA is analysing the actual situation to enter a trade. Most of time it will not open a new position. If all the conditions are met, it will open a trade.

Thanks ActionPL for your help.   
  
I have concerns about the risk of this system.   
  
It has a large SL @ 300 pips and opens 5 positions when the market is going against us. Then it hedges those positions. If we are trading 8 pairs the worst case scenario is we have a total of 40 positions open. If the market moves against us (trend change) we could conceivably be in very large drawdown and even margin call. The question then has to be asked, what is our total overall risk to our account (VaR)? I don't think this issue has been adequately addressed? Since we are going down the automated route, perhaps a coder could implement an advanced money management routine to allow the trader to control risk more effectively. I for one think this is a great system but we need to prepare for the worst should it occur.   
  
Any thoughts?  
  
Cheers  
  
Spy

Hi,  
  
I'll do these things to control the risk:  
1\. position size properly to have lotsize number such that 300pips stop is only 1R risk (my 1R is 3% of my total capital)  
2\. set MaxOpenOrders to 2-3, i see this still yield good result in my backtest  
3\. use Main_*Trend_Alert_ rather than *_Trade_Alert_ which will not open reverse position when trendline broken  
4\. use default Reduce_factor=2, it'll cut the stoploss by half when trendline broken. thus, if you have 2 open orders and the trend reverse, the total risk will be lower down to 1R rather than 2R originally

The new rules will prevent us to have two open positions buy and sell at the end of the day. So, you can't use the Option Trade_ in your description. (For version 1.4a and up)  
The FIFO rule will in fact restrict us to have only one trade open at a given time. So we will need to set variable MaxOpenOrder = 1.   
I did not see any reference that will prevent us to use Stop Lost or Take Profit.   
If you have some information about that, please send me the link.  
  
We will need to find a new setup that will produce good results with those constraints.![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f601.png?v=15.1)

so if i want to have the EA start trading long on a break of a horizontal trendline (resistance) when in a range i would use #???   
  
i tried various combinations below in strategy tester but, i ended up with buys and sells opening in the test when i only wanted long. i had trendline_watch=true. should trendanalysis be on too by the way for a scenario where i only wanted to initiate trading on the break of a trendline? i tried first with it on and it wouldn't open any trades in this scenario so i turned it off and it started trading but, i got some sell trades when i didn't want any.  
  
i'm using v 1.5c  
  
it would be helpful if there was a quality document created and maintained that covered the evolving trendline syntax and trade examples. i have seen A LOT of people having to ask these specific questions.  
  
thanks for all the generosity in sharing.  
  
**1. ****Alert_30: If price action come close to this trend by 30 pips by either side.**  
**2. ****DownTrend_Alert_ :If price action come above this trendline**  
**3. ****UpTrend_Alert_: If price action come below this trendline**  
**4. ****UpTrend_Close_Alert_: Same as 3 but will close all open buy order**  
**5. ****DownTrend_Close_Alert_: Same as 2 but will close all open sell order**  
**6. ****UpTrend_Trade_Alert_30: Same as 3 but will initiate a sell trade if price action go 30 pips below the uptrend**  
**7. ****DownTrend_Trade_Alert_30: Same as 2 but will initiate a buy trade if price action go 30 pips above the downtrend.**  
**8. ****UpTrend_Close_Trade_Alert_30: Will close all buy trade before doing 6**  
**9. ****DownTrend_Trade_Alert_30: Will close all sell trade before doing 7**

I did some more research on this new rules. Here the link to read the new rules. Go at the end of this report. <http://forex-systems-reviews.com/NFAreport.pdf>. This report will also gave you a list of brokers with their responce to those new rules. __**A MUST TO READ  
  
**__As you can see, Stoploss and Take profit will still work.   
Edging will not work from day to day but will work on a given day.  
FIFO rule will prevent us to have multiple order with the same lot size. So this mean that with version 1.5c and earlier, you will need to set variable   
MaxOpenOrders=1 if you want to follow this rule.  
  
There is a way to get around that, it is to have lot size change for eah trade. I will have to change the EA so it will change the lot size by an increment that you will specify each time a trade is open. This way, we will not go agains the FIFO rules starting the 1 of August. So the first trade will be at 0.1 lot, the second trade will be at 0.11 lot and so on.(If the increment is 0.01 and if your broker accept microlot). I will have the EA customize in such a way that people will be able to select the initial lot size as we have now and the increment. So you will be able to customize it to your broker requirement.  
  
I can't guarantee that this will be ready for the 1st of August since it required change to the code and i will be in vacation.![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f44d.png?v=15.1) So next version will have this feature and the improvement on trailling stop fonction as described last week.   
  
Have a great summer.![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
  
Bye  
Actionpl

I think to have a better risk managemend we should include in the EA code, the strategy of scaling in and out of positions, basically let's say we have this situation:  
  
**1)** We open a trade of 0,3 lots with tp of 90 pips.  
**2)** At +30 pips the robots closes 0,1 of the position and moves the take profit to breakeven.  
**3)** At +60 pips the robots closes the other 0,1 of the position and if the price goes to +90 pips we're out with a total of 180 pips with 0,1 lotsize, if not it will go to the stoploss wich is at breakeven and we don't lose a penny and we get 90 pips with 0,1 lot size.  
  
If you don't get it, [see here](http://blogs.fxstreet.com/fxpath/2009/07/17/scaling-in-and-scaling-out/)  
  
There already are some ea that do this but we can attach 2 eas on the same chart so we have to include it in the code or have 2 MT4 opened for the same account with the 2 eas attached.

This is my first post on FX factory, mostly because I didnt feel I had enough forex knowlege until now to make an edjucated post.  
  
Anyways here it goes... I have been up and down this thread expermenting with different settings for the multiple Firebird EA's that are available. I have been using a strategy utilizing these systems on a live account for about a month now and has shown to be profitable. I know a month is short term however I have a good reason to believe the strategy will work for long term as well.  
  
The strategy utilizes both full auto and semi driven firebirds.   
As TheGabriel has mentioned the full auto system works very well on a ranging market but not trending.  
So I have been trading 8 currencies at a time (the number of charts works well in a verticle sortment on MT4) and placing the fully auto firebird on only markets that are ranging, and then placing the semi auto firebird on the markets that are trending.  
  
My results have been very pleasing. I have about 85% win rate and all my losses occured with the trending market which I have the semi auto version running which reduces S/L to 150 pips. Also my gains in the trending markets have been higher due to trailing S/L.  
  
Now, I understand that the system can draw down your account and cause margin call, however if that happens it is most likely due to poor money management. Such as the above post having $900 and working with .1 (mini) lots. With that high of a risk he only needed 3 losses on the full auto ea and his account is vanished! 3 losses!!! IMO that is not good money management. I have been trading micro .01 lots and will increase the lot size by .01 every $200-$300 made. This way before I even reach the mini lot size I will have close to $5,000 in the account.  
  
I am not an experienced trader (only about 3 months experience) but I do know good money management and I do know a good system when i see one and i believe this is it, I just hope it works long term.  
  
Thats just my .02 cents

Hi ayoneeyee and others, try this version, it has many new features and some bugs fix.  
  
New features:   
1- Will change the trade size by what is in variable "Lots_Increment" each time a new trade is activated while having a trade open. This will allow us to go around the FIFO rule.  
2- Allow to have hidden profit and hidden stoploss when variable "TrailingStopFlag" is true. Lood at variable "Hidden_Take_Profit". To desactivate Hidden profit, set this variable larger than the TakeProfit variable. To activate the hidden stop lost, you need to have profit larger than "TakeProfit-TStrigger". So if your TakeProfit is at 1000, set your TStrigger at 1010. This way your hidden stoplost will be what you have set in variable TrailingStop as soon the trade is open.  
3- A new dynamic trailingStop feature have been added. If you want your trailing stop to be the previous low from time frame set by variable "Auto_Chart_time" which is lower than the (acual Bid - TrailingStop_margin) for a buy, set variable TrailingStopDynamic at true  
4- Now the EA will take track of individual trailingStop for a given pair even if you have many trade open on the same pair.  
5- Fix bugs in trailingStop fonction  
6- For those who are using the TrendLine_watch = true, The EA will automatically place a Main_XTrend_Alert_ when price action will touch either an UpTrend_Alert_ or a DownTrend_Alert_. So on a flat market, you can place a UpTrend_Alert_ under the lows and a DownTrend_Alert_ above the trading range and when price action will hit the UpTrend_Alert_ trend line, it will trace a Main_Down_Alert_ above the last high of the time frame set by variable "Auto_Chart_time". And the opposite if it hit the DownTrend. Whith this fonction you can set your EA to monitor the market and start trade when conditions are met.  
  
Try this version and let me know how it work. Make sure your trade on demo with this version before you go live. This have many tool in the tool boxe to set up your trades. So you need to experiment and get confident with it before doing any life trade.  
  
Best regards  
Actionpl![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f62c.png?v=15.1)

So if we consider the market flat, you suggest in Autotrade Section to set Manage_Trade = true and in TrendAnalysis Section to set TrendLine_Watch = true and TrendAnalysis = false.  
Manage_Trade is only a flag to prevent the EA to trade agains Heiken Ashi indicator. This indicator is working well with trend. On trendless period, you are going to get hit with badtrade.  
TrendLine_Watch flag is to set the EA in a mode to detect when to start trade. So in trendless period, you set this flag at true and place an UpTrend_Alert and a DownTrend_Alert so when price action hit one of those, it will start to trade in the direction that the market want to go. So your skill of how to place those trendline are very important.  
So if you combine both of those flag and your are right to detect a trend, it will produce good results.  
  
Bye  
Actionpl

Hi Inquisitor, version 1.5d have a variable that allow to have profit taken which is hidden from broker. Check this variable "Hidden_TakeProfit" in section Trailing Stop. P.S. you need to activate trailing stop in order to have this feature to take effect.  
  
Also the default setup have trailing stop activated and the dynamic trailing stop activated. This feature will change the trailling stop to the previous bar low or high. This is a good feature for pair with high volatility. If you don't want that feature, set variable "TrailingStopDynamic" to false.

Hi ActionPL,  
  
Have not as yet tested FB Vs_5d. Been running Vs_5c live for quite a while, doing v well with it. But, collected a real clanger this week using it.  
  
In 3 seconds, it opened and closed 21 trades with an average loss of 4 pips each = 81 pips.  
  
Started with me testing the trailing stop function (1st time I used it) so I fortunately used the minimum lot size (thank goodness!). Currency was GU, spread 4 pips.  
  
The UpTrend Trade started OK, went into good profit, then reversed, I figured it would go into loss. I then made a mistake which I think was the cause of the problem. I created a new "Main_UpTrend_Alert_05" trend-line, while the first trade was still running and active. The trade re-traced, went to -18 pips, which was the value in the SL (from the trailing stop function) and closed the trade on -18pips. Then it all went wrong; it immediately opened a new trade, saw it was below the previous Trailing stop point, and closed it immediately - 3 pips loss! And again, 5pip loss and again and again, 21 times in 3 seconds. Fortunately, I returned to the PC as this happened, else it could have been a real disaster!   
  
Will be great if you can close this gap in the EA in case a similar error is made by someone else. Same may apply to Vs1_5d?  
  
I have been using Vs1_5c in its basic semiauto form, with simple rules, and tight trend lines so that I can bail-out with minimum losses. Only used in very trending conditions.  
  
Have been using Vs1_3b when market ranges, will post settings used in another post.  
  
Bye  
  
Andy

Hi everyone,  
  
For those interested in using this EA as fully automatic, when the Vs1_5c is not suitable.  
  
Using this live. I have not made big profits, I'm happy if I get 20-25 pips/day - I think the secret is in defining when straight-lining /ranging starts and ends. I keep getting it wrong!  
  
Use Vs 1_3b only when "straight-lining", and set to trade both "long & short" - NOT during trends, which will clean you out. Therefore, you need to also "drive" 3b but in a different way compared to 5c and 5d where you use trend-lines. I use it on a 5 min chart. Only use when trends dissappear - check the PA - put MA 10, MA 21, MA 50 on your chart, and when they criss-cross often then switch the EA ON. Soon as they split-up and start moving out of the trade price range area that you assess as suitable for trading the EA, then you switch the EA OFF. Once OFF, I trade manually - when conditions right, the Philip Nel 5M Intra-day System with the above MA 10, 21 and 50 - see his thread <http://www.forexfactory.com/showthread.php?t=11854>. When a major trend continues for more than a day, I look to using vs1_5c.   
  
Once 3b is set and running, I check on it periodically (every 1 hr) to see developing trends and perhaps switch-off. When I switch-off, I kill the last trade if PA is going wrong way. Do not trade it within 1 - 2 hours before major news items - switch off.   
  
Saw an earlier post where large SL is used with 3b. Not a good idea, it WILL clean you out. The nature of 3b is such that if you run it with TP40 and SL40 for +4 weeks, then it will be like flipping a coin, will come out about square, but with some big draw-downs. Overall, a 80TP and 40SL will give better returns, but the draw-downs can get VERY big. In back-testing, over broken 6 week ranging periods, net profits were +570 pips - it did have 6-8 consecutive loss trades in one period. This is all to stressful.  
  
I prefer using a small TP of 5, max 8. SL 100 is for emergency only, I kill the last trade when I detect a trend starting. I use pairs with small spread - EU, UJ. Multi pairs can be profitable, but when trends develope, it can become frantic to reduce potential losses.   
  
FB Vs1_3b Settings used are (4 digit broker):  
Chart_Time_Frame = 5  
MA_Length = 10  
MA_Timeframe = 15  
MAtype = 0  
Percent = 0.05  
TradeonFriday = 1  
Slip = 10  
Lots = 0.nn  
MaxOpenOrders = 1 (keep it simple)  
SafeArea = 5000  
PipStep = 25 (try smaller numbers, yes?)  
TakeProfit = 5   
StopLoss = 100 (try 40 or 60, yes?)  
TrailingStopFlag = false  
TrailingStop = 40  
TStrigger = 20  
MinMarginLevel = 25.0  
Trade from / to = your preference, I only switch on when I'm available to "supervise" the EA  
DivergenceLimit = 0.005 (0.10 for Jpy pairs)  
Other fields - use defaults  
  
Enjoy your trading!  
  
Andy

Correct. I use 100 SL as I'm not always at the PC, therefore need to give the trade room to move. However, when I'm present and I see a trend developing, then I kill the trade immediately. Problem can be that one is already at the 80 - 90 pip loss point on returning to the PC, in which case you're looking at a big loss. Alternative strategy is to use a SL of 40 - 50pips, which you could hit more often. Experiment.  
  
If you activate the EA when the PA is straight-lining, you will see that it does make quite a few profitable trades. Win some profit trades then quit - if you leave it running for long periods, you will hit the SL.   
  
If I'm present at the PC for extended periods, then I prefer to trade manually with higher lots sizes, whereas with the EA's (3b or 5c) I use smaller lot sizes - use the smallest (0.01) to start with.   
  
Enjoy!  
  
Andy

Hi, the only think i can see that can cause this kind of behavior is the following.  
When you have trace a new Main trendline, you must have put it to close from the Price Action. So As long as you did not release left button on the mouse, the EA was not able to reset the description if it was hit. So it repeat itself. When you trace a trend line close to price action, do it fast and don't put it too close of PA.   
I will continue to monitor the EA, let me know if this happen while you did not touch the trend line, let me know.  
  
Best of luck ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)

Hi markpips,  
I had the same problem, so I'm trying the following to correct the situation:  
I generally use the Demark trend (daily) for entry. I use default settings except for the usdjpy or eurjpy DivergenceLimit which needs to be increased (default is .002). I didn't know what to use, so I kept increasing until the error disappeared. I settled on .01. After entry I move the trend line down/up to about the SL and this gives the PA room for retracements. I also use the Sonic Channel to confirm the trend. I am comfortable with a 2 to 3 o'clock up channel angle for a buy or 4 to 5 o'clock down channel angle for a sell. Same for the trend lines. Also I try not to enter a buy near the top of a channel or a sell near the bottom of a channel. Don't forget to use money management to determine your lot size. I risk 1 to 1.5 percent so that my loss isn't too great when a trade goes the wrong way. Once a trailing stop is established, I just let it go. Good luck.

Hi alain1,  
After establishing your trend line, double click on it so that the three boxes appear on you trend line. Next right click on the trend line and select trendline properties on the drop down. Write Main_UpTrend_Alert_, etc. on the description line. Be careful to pay atention to the caps. In order to view what you wrote you have to select any blank area of the chart and right click. Select properties on the dropdown. Select the Common Tab and check the bottom box "Show object descriptions". Trendline inscriptions should now appear. Discussions about this start on page 107 or 108. I'm having problems with 1.5d so I'm still using 1.5c. Good luck.

  * [![](https://assets.faireconomy.media/nfs/customavatars/thumbs/medium/avatar99536_2.gif) JohnnyBSmart](johnnybsmart)

  * Joined Apr 2009 | Status: Trader | [816 Posts](/search?do=process&provider=Member&searchuser=99536)

Hello Fellow Traders,  
  
I have just finished reading a few dozen posts in this thread. It seems very similar to an idea I had a year or so ago. Not having read the entire thread it might have already been discussed but here goes. Having written a few automatic trading systems myself the key to any good system of course is filtering out the little bumps in the road so as not to place a trade too early. Even a trend line won't do that. It can really irritate the trader watching the PA continuing on its merry way after you already jumped off the train.  
  
Now I'm most likely posting this way too early in my understanding of this method but what caught my attention was the mentioning of a trend line. If you are manually drawing or even a code drawn line the buy and sell signals are still the same. Even with trend lines a bump in the road will occur and filtering these is critical to maximizing the trades.  
  
I have experimented with many different methods and one that seems to work the best is the stochastic K & D values. The mistake most coders of EA's do is write values to cross a fixed position or values such as the K value crossing a value of 80 signals a buy which is totally wrong as even the value 100 shows up in the middle of a long uptrend. The other problem is the PA reaching a high pivot point and never hitting 80 which makes the trade a loser when the PA promptly falls off a cliff.  
  
The best way to move the trade forward after hitting a high mark such as a trend line cross over or an indicator cross of a value is to have a filter such as stochastics K less than D on sells or D less than K on longs with adjustable settings. Let’s look at some examples below:  
  
On the M5 chart the PA moves across a trend line after a long down trend which ended at 9:00. The filter checks the value of stochastics K vs. D only after the first requirement of crossing the trend line is met.  
  
K Long setting = 5, K Short setting = 5  
  
EXAMPLE “A”  
  
9:00 PA = 1.5000 K = 5, D = 8  
  
9:05 PA = 1.5010 K = 20, D = 12, Long trade is made.  
  
EXAMPLE “B”  
  
9:00 PA = 1.5000 K = 5, D = 8  
  
9:05 PA = 1.5010 K = 13, D = 12, Long trade is NOT made.  
  
9:10 PA = 1.5020 K = 25, D = 18, Long trade is made.  
  
The PA can actually reverse and the initial trade never made due to the K settings not being reached. A second trade takes over at a much lower PA level which is what we are trying to accomplish.  
  
Other things must also be coded into the EA such as severe downtrends where a counter trend trade is particularly foolish and doesn’t move enough to cover the cost. This can be accomplished with simple codes and why most programs do not address this is crazy. At the very least counter trend trades should be looked at as topping out after crossing a MA-9 value and the K & D filter initiated after reaching no matter what the K or D value or what the slope of the PA for that matter. This will lock in positive trades before reversing in the middle of Bollinger Band channels. You will notice a lot of times the Stochastics value has reached a maximum value although the PA has topped out in the middle of an LRC, Price Channel or Bollinger Band Channel. Another way to recognize the PA trend is the Upper and Lower Bollinger Band values which keeps the trade from ever happening in a quickly consolidating PA. If you can stay out of the bad part of town you will stay a lot healthier.  
  
On an EA which includes stochastics I’ve had success with settings such as 5 and 95 on the K low and high settings which are the high success trades. After back testing the high success trades I then code the harder trades such as countertrend trades.  
  
I’ve also used this method with great success by adding code for Doji recognition and then initiating the filter. Any high or low value of any indicator seems to work great. The program just ignores all other bumps in the road unless a setting is hit to initiate the filter and thus a buy or sell signal. An exception is when the PA is in tight consolidation and trades are halted. If a trade is already in progress then it plays out. Drawing a channel of the consolidation with the PA highs and lows and initiating the filter after a break up or down restarts the program.  
  
Another useful add-in is code for the sudden huge moves that can move the stochastic K value from zero to 100 in one bar and then back down again the next bar. Percent of PA increase and decrease can handle these moves and buy or sell before initiating the filter. The possible downside is if the PA continues moving in that direction such as with some of the violent reversal moves at the start of this recession. Once all of your indicators top out and the PA is still moving though the roof, now what do you do? This actually happened to me as I was watching the EA trade the PA crossed an Upper Bols Band and stochastics K value hit 100. I was sitting with a nice profit and was waiting for the Short trade when the PA shot up like a rocket on the next bar and then the next and the next. A $6,000 additional move just occurred and I’m still in the game. The sell trade was finally satisfied. I had just redone the code from a hard sell at 100 to using the filter. I was just lucky this didn’t happen after a down bar and then it wood have hit my sell stop which is a large $400 per contract. Having anything less then that means you don’t trust your own program to handle the bumps in the road.   
  
The other thing that keeps showing up is all the excuses being made why their EA didn’t work at a particular time or doesn’t work on some currency pairs. That to me is just plain bull crap. A chart is a chart whether its currency pairs, stocks or whatever. Either the program works or it doesn’t work. It’s just that simple. I just read one that starts out saying his program was designed for GBPUSD. I’d like to know how he did that. What he should have said was it was the only pair that made any money and on all the rest he lost his butt. He’s publishing this hoping someone with more intelligence and trading experience can fix his screw-ups.  
  
All of the above I learned the hard way and I’m hoping some of you young coders will learn something about programming an EA from this. One thing I must add is the RSI indicator I would stay clear of as a filter as it doesn’t work well in this type of set-up. Another is the simple fact that unless the EA is based on a trend line with an indicator for filtering the cross all single indicator EA’s are not going to work all of the time or will they work on all charts. The fact is they will blow up your account.  
  
I have back tested this on the Daily chart with a semi-auto system over a 1 1/2 year period with only one loss of $50. I also did a similar test on the one hour with vitually the same results but just more trades. It works on all charts and on all time frames. I just don't have it for MT4 which is why I'm looking here at thia system.  
  
I hope this helps somebody and also hoping somebody that is a great coder takes the bull by the horns and programs these ideas into this program.  
  
Trade well and prosper,  
  
Johnny

Hello Prakash,  
  
Sorry I took so long to answer back. The point I was as making was the 5-8 EMA cross is garbage. The K-D values are much better but there are a number of better signals. Understand the optimum K-D values will vary with the settings of the stochastics.  
  
The other key point is the program itself which is not a bad visual aid for guiding the trader over a few bumps in the road but fails to stop the train at the main terminal so you can get off with maximum pips. The train by passes the station by five miles. The getting on the train is just as dangerous as by the time it finds out the direction it's heading a lot of it's cargo of pips got run over by the train.  
  
The solution and the way to design and code an efficient EA is to jump to the high/low points on the higher time frames. After the PA has reached these high/low points based on user input such as 80-20 stochastic values the trade is moved to the M1 chart values. The code then loops the exit/entry criteria such as the K-D values or a trailing stop is initiated. Both actually are necessary depending on the S & R values reached which again are user input values.  
  
The S & R values are indicators such as the Bollinger Bands or other lines of S & R. This method ignores all of the bumps in the road and it goes from point A to Z ignoring B-Y.![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f601.png?v=15.1)  
  
It really is the most logical way to get to Z. If you were planning a trip from NY to LA the quickest and most direct route is to take a jet. This way the Mississippi River and the Rocky Mountains are not bumps in the road we have to worry about. Now the fact is that sometimes the jet might land in Reno and you have to board another flight but you will get to LA in the end.  
  
This type of trading system tells you the plane first has to go by way of Boston and leaves three hours late. It then lands in Chicago and lets you off without a continuing flight and no refund. When you finally get a flight out to LA at additional expense it by passes LA by 500 miles. They give you a parachute so you can jump out and hopefully land on a small deserted island in the middle of the Pacific Ocean. You're very reluctant to do this but the Plane is out of gas and going to crash land anyway so you jump. Now your praying and hoping you land safely but the cold hard fact is the water is shark infested and the landing zone is very small.![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f64f.png?v=15.1) Don't forget to close your eyes if you're like me and afraid of the sight of your own blood. LOL.![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f923.png?v=15.1)  
  
The sharks (Professional traders) are always looking for juicy little snacks like you as we never stop eating.  
  
So if you're going to write an EA you must design it around good S & R values as well as a decent Entry and Exit. Without thoroughly understanding how to trade, no EA will fix that problem. The coder will only code to his ability and knowledge of trading or the lack of it which is so prevalent on the internet.:nerd:  
  
I see posts on many forums proclaiming money making EA's only to find a close to 50-50 win/lose ratio and bigger losses then winners. This one proudly shows a $12 million plus loss and a $9 million win and proclaims a 1.7 profit factor. Now I'm not an Einstein when it comes to math but even Jethro of the Beverly Hillbillies with a sixth grade education could figure this is not a good system.  
  
I had a retired engineer call me on the phone after posting on an automatic trading system thread asking me for advice about a system he was purchasing to supplement his retirement income. He stated it was a real money maker and it only cost $1400 initially and $400 a month there after. I asked him to email the analysis so I could see the win loss ratio and the $ loss / $ investment ratio on both the back and forward tests. He said he didn't have any of that type of information but the program produced 53% wins. I could tell by the way this guy was talking that his mind was already made up and no explanation of the facts from me was going to change this pilgrim's direction to the promise land. Now if an Engineer can be so stupid and not recognize that just flipping a coin will get you 50% then what is the hope of the multitude of people that can't grasp basic math and believe everything they read like the Martian found walking around NY or the talking pig in Iowa. I think our government hires way too many of these people and makes them bank examiners. They're all members of the "Be Kind to Dumb Animals Club". I think it's their natural preservation instinct.  
  
Let me know how you make out with this EA.  
  
Happy trades,  
  
Johnny

Hello 1800forex,  
  
Undoubtedly you're a newbie or at the very least not versed in the qualities of a good EA. Don't be blinded by the profits shown on the website as a better gauge of the good, the bad and the ugly is the losses and the profit factor. The profit factor of 1.9 is very low to the point of ridiculas. Anybody worth their salt as a trader could write a better performimg EA blind folded. My very first attempt at writing an EA as a newbie coder many years ago was 50 times higher than this.  
  
Understand that a professional trader looks for no less then 95% wins and would expect no less from an EA. This EA isn't even in the same ballpark and is obviously written by somebody who doesn't fully understand trading. The problem with these incomplete EA's is they can look good on some currency pairs some of the time but fail miserably most of the time. They cannot be traded on any chart or security and the seller will usually say I wrote this EA around a particular currency pair which is pure bull crap. The truth be known is that they kept looking until they found one that showed a profit. A decent EA will work on any chart whether it be currency, stocks or options. The mathematical formulas behind an EA don't know the difference between stocks or currency pairs because it's all just looking at the numbers.  
  
There are a few fair producing EA's on the internet but this isn't one of them. I've only ever found one worth anything at all. If you invest a dime on something like this you're an idiot and you should have the letters "DFI" tattood on your forehead.  
  
Learn to trade first before looking for the holy grail EA,  
  
Johnny

This is a script created by Steve Hopwood that sets/adjusts stops, opens/closes trades, steps, trails...basically a complete trade management tool.  
I use it quite often to set a global % SL so that of all trades that are open, it can take profit or stop loss at a defined $ amount or %. You can set it to only affect a particular magic number or all trades, etc. There's quite a bit of documentation + the tool ((free) at the site below.  
Hope you guys find it as useful as I do,

Hi guys,  
  
I have been trying the template given by Samuraipower... the one which shows Heiken Ashi Candles, a yellow 21-EMA, and the indicator which shows arrows that signal buy and sell.  
  
But I noticed one thing... (i dunno if it's my imagination... But I assure you, I am recording things on a journal)...  
  
Sometimes, the indicator (w/ arrows) shows buy/sell signals on the previous candle, but suddenly, in the middle of the day, the signal of the PREVIOUS candle just disappears. This usually happens when the signal is opposite of what the market is doing. It seems that the indicator is hiding its mistake? ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f615.png?v=15.1)![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/2753.png?v=15.1)  
  
Let me give an example:  
  
The daily candle of GBP/JPY showed a BUY on 09/12/10. So on the open of the candle of 09/13/10, I entered a BUY trade. Unfortunately, GBP/JPY went south instead of north (horrors! a 100+ loss). And guess what... the BUY signal generated on the 09/12/10 candle is nowhere to be found!!   
  
This is mysterious for me because, I traded on the candle **_AFTER_** the candle which showed the signal.   
  
Have you encountered this?  
  
I think this occurrence can really endanger the reliability of the EA, since we would sometimes be driving it in the wrong direction.  
  
Feedback would be appreciated.

gasgas  
  
Thank you for your question. I trade with the 30/60/120 ema on the 4hr as part of my trading repertiore that includes the (GU intraday system-my creation). Now the key to using this EA as long as price remains below the 120 ema with the 30 and 60 ema in line, I remain short and vice versa. I only change when I have a daily close above or below the 120 ema. (I adjust the ea only on a daily close.  
  
Then I enter the trade in the direction of the new trend. At this time I am watching the last swing low or high on the 4 hr as a confirmation of the new trend as long as price does not break below that low the new trend is valid(definetly there would be a pull back).  
  
Otherwise the simpler way is to search for pairs with already established trends using the 3 emas and drive the ea that way. For example this is the chart of the euraud, you can see what happened when price broke the 120 ema on the 4 hr price pulled back and found support there. This also concided with the 1.4000 round number barrier zone. So we have a daily close above and I will drive the ea long until price breaks below and closes off the 120 ema on a daily close. Trading like this you would have less whipsaws and catch those big moves that the forex market is known for.  
It also gives you time to check up on the market news and know what is driving price action, thereby giving you more confidence on your trades. I hope this helps.

Alright guys sorry, I did not answer your questions immediately.   
  
1\. I trade all the majors including the major exotic pairs.   
  
2\. I trade the EA with the ATR value of each pair. i trade using 3 trades for each pair with a total risk exposue of 6 per cent  
  
3\. I first run through all the pairs looking for established trends using the 30/60/120 ema. These are the pairs I give priority. Then I keep my eyes on potential trades. Go through the charts with just the 3 emas and you can see how effective this system is.  
  
4\. I use the same ea on this thread, i just drive the ea either short or long.  
  
5\. Never trade without a stop loss.  
  
6\. I use the default pip step but may adjust by 10-20 pips depending on the volatility of the pair.  
  
7\. Fundamentally, I am always long audusd and audjpy cause of the high interest rate differential.

Zukies thanks for the complement, but actually is nothing new.  
  
Please take note we only trade **the 4hr chart and not daily. The EMAs are only for the 4 hr chart.**  
  
For example when price breaks above the 120 ema on the 4hr chart.We would like to see **a daily close** **with price above the 120 ema on the 4hr chart**. Before we have a valid change of trend and thereby drive the EA in that direction.   
  
You would now place the EA main trend line to pass through the swing low of the price swing that broke the 120 ema, because usually price would retrace and if it is a valid change of trend it would not break that low. So we would have the ea enter the new trend at a discount (usually I use 40 pips step on the usd pairs and 50-55 on the jpy pairs). This was the case with the eurusd which I immensely benefited from.  
  
The euraud as I adviced in my earlier post is already in an uptrend , remember break of **120 ema on 4hr chart** and if you had entered as I showed in the chart I posted earlier you would already be in the money.  
  
But guys note that I stop driving the ea in the direction of the trend when the **daily chart is overdone. That is when the daily rsi is above 70 or under 30**. It means a reversal may be in place and usually price at such levels reverse quickly.  
  
I hope this helps

greven if you have traded the ea on this thread you would see it has a provison for entering the number of trades you want as price moves against you.   
  
Every Pair has a different daily range value and we want to have realisitc stop loss and take profit levels. For example the daily range of EU is 138. So I calculate my stop loss/ take profit using values from 1, 1.5 or 2 x ADR. What that means is that we would survive any minor retracement against the trend and enter on a discount as the ea takes trades in the direction of the prevailing trend. Because we have used realistic take profit levels we expect our objective to be hit within 2 days and as price retraces the ea enters at a discount and the cycle continues.   
Remeber when you are trend trading you can only be wrong once. That is when the trend breaks and reverses. Off course the EA,s trend line functionality is an added advantage as it reduces the stop loss by half if price touches the trend line.  
  
Also note that we want to identify and profit from the meduim term trend. That is why we use the 30/60/120 ema on the 4hr. A quick look through all the charts in your charting package would reveal how few whipsaws you would have using the 3EMAs to determine trend direction.

Finally before I take my break today.  
  
To help confirm the trend direction when trading USD pairs apply the 30/60/120 ema on a 4 hr chart of the US Dollar Index(professional trading tip![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f910.png?v=15.1)). The trend on that index will determine dollar stength or weakness on all your forex pairs.  
  
For yen pairs the general rule is Usd Jpy determines overall trend direction of the yen pairs. However it is not as definite as the dollar index. In most cases when the dollar is weak on all fronts the other yen pairs are quite choppy.

I do not use a fixed tp/sl. I usually use 1.5 Atr to set my stops and targets. The rational behind the 1.5 is that in my opinion on a healthy trend price will pull back but would not close below the previous day low. So I believe that if price pulls back and hits my stops which is 1.5 ATR then the trend is weakening.

Szabolcs,  
yes, The stop loss is hard coded in the firebird to 200 or 300 pips..  
but, we should monitor the trades with a MA stop loss EA (for forward testing) to reflect the effect of my back testing...  
  
so that the MA trail stop takes over the fixed stop once the firebird is running..(provided price moves above or below the 24 ema)  
  
**In my forward testing..**  
yes, I am using the trend lines...I think thats the only way to make this thing work in a specific direction based on the trend.  
  
Also, I am using this EA for my MA trailing stop loss (same pair but a different chat)  
[http://www.forexfactory.com/showpost...59&postcount=4](http://www.forexfactory.com/showpost.php?p=3589959&postcount=4)  
  
and the settings are explained here:  
[http://www.forexfactory.com/showpost...36&postcount=6](http://www.forexfactory.com/showpost.php?p=3590336&postcount=6)  
  
yes, let us know how the system works for you...  
its basically a trend system with multiple orders at small intervals...  
and not letting any of these series of trades go out of control by using an EMA trailing stop loss.  
  
Thanks.

sergen4,  
There will be small losses..when the price is hugging around the 24 ema..  
refer to the blue areas in my post 1956.  
these are inevitable..we are helpless..the market will slice us anyways...  
but since we have tight control with 24 ema..we do not lose much..  
I havent taken the trades in the blue areas into consideration..  
but, I can tell you its **negligent** considering the overall gains.  
  
You could limit your DD by manipulating these 2 variables in the settings:  
**_The settings for back tests are as follows:_**  
  
s0="Section for Trend Analysis"; TrendAnalysis=false; EmailAlert=false; PopupAlert=false; TrendLine_watch=false; Reduce_factor=2; Trend_line_Keep=3; AutoTrend_timeperiod=240; s1="Section for Autotrade"; Manage_Trade=false; Heiken_Ashi_timeperiod=240; index=1; email=false; s2="Section for FireBird"; Chart_Time_Frame=5; MA_length=21; MA_timeframe=5; MAtype=1; Percent=0.05; TradeOnFriday=1; slip=25; Lots=0.1; **MaxOpenOrders=5** ; SafeArea=10000; **PipStep=100** ; TakeProfit=1000; Stoploss=2000; s3="Section for Trailing stop"; TrailingStopFlag=false; TrailingStop=200; TStrigger=200; MinMarginLevel=250; TradeFrom1=0; TradeUntil1=24; TradeFrom2=0; TradeUntil2=0; TradeFrom3=0; TradeUntil3=10; TradeFrom4=0; TradeUntil4=0; s4="Section for iFXAnalyzer"; Fast_Period=23; Fast_Price=1; Slow_Period=84; Slow_Price=1; DivergenceLimit=0.1; Use_V63D_Divergence=false; IncreasementType=0; PipsLoss=500; GMT=2; DST=0; OpeningHour=0; ClosingHour=24; writelog=0;   
  
**MaxOpenOrders=5** (max. no. of open trades at one time floating); reducing this...will surely decrease the drawdown..  
  
  
**PipStep=100** (opens a trade at every 10 pips); increase to 20 or 40, would reduce the DD as well..  
  
But, keep in mind that this will reduce your gains **significantly**.  
  
Go for it..  
I would love to see your results.  
  
Thanks,

but..I just changed it to grid trader ea.  
_**  
Attached please find my screen shots of euro 4h chart with the cornflower tpl.  
  
The way I take trades or start my automation of trades (meaning in real time : turn on the grid trader ea), is when the price crosses the cornflower EMA...i.e. EMA 24....  
AND at the same time I use this same EMA as my stop loss...  
so, my stop loss is being moved along the 24 ema up or down, depending on the direction of the trend..

as explained by Lever70

and my exit (red line)..  
REMEMBER, cornflower EMA is controlling my entry and exit.

The ONLY read reason why I'm going BACK is 20% deposit and 1.5 pip rebates, so, get yourself 5m GBP/USD chart, put firebird on this one, then put a daily on with Parabolics, then just change when par changes ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f609.png?v=15.1) I'm running as we speak, haven't lost anything DRASTICALLY yet ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f609.png?v=15.1) AND the 1.5 pip rebate (which you HAVE to register for on your account...SEPERATELY by the way but you get paid immediately onto your account as you trade) ALSO helps put $$ in your pocket. Look, I've always liked lite even though they suck with EA's, I KNOW they pay, never had problems with that so I reckon this would be good combo esp for people working full time. All you do is check once a day (I do in mornings) where you SAR is sitting, if the SAR has changed close open orders and change around. As I said before, you WILL get serious dd but hey, nowdays every bit helps ($$ wise), just a quick backtest on couple months shows some decent results even if one has some ranging to go through and lose couple pips. par is parabolic sar, when it changes direction you change direction too, but here's another idea which I'm also going to try, instead of upping your lot size IMMEDIATELY once your balance is certain amount, rather wait for par SAR to change direction, THEN up your lot size if you want because I've seen in lots of backtests that when SAR is about to change over there are some trades which will end in negative (even if a small amount), one DOESN'T really know HOW long the trend is going to last this is why i say ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f609.png?v=15.1) don't quote me as scripture here, I just think is good idea  
Hope this helps  
(The way I see it, doesn't matter WHAT indicators you use whether MA's, CCI, or WHATEVER, SOMEWHERE you'll get loss, and this method I think IS about the easiest and you'll score pips in the market), you'll just have huge draw down that's it)
